ns0:entry.ns0:content:
Lancaster  University is going to launch an online course on #corpus #linguistics starting in January 2014 - https://www.futurelearn.com/courses/corpus-linguistics.

It is aimed at researchers so not sure if #language #teachers   will be interested but as it's free no harm in checking it out when it does launch. :)

In the meantime there is already a great online course (aimed at #translators ); units 1 and 2 are great primers for those new to corpora whilst the other units are very interesting for further study. e.g. unit on regular expressions.

You can use it as a guest or register for a free account
http://parles.upf.edu/llocs/moodle/course/view.php?id=311
http://parles.upf.edu/llocs/moodle/course/view.php?id=311

Reading Concordances by John Sinclair is a great tutorial book - http://mssesteachers.wikispaces.com/file/view/Reading_Concordances--An_Introduction+(4).pdf.

It shows you in detail how to go about working with concordances. Highly worth spending time on I would say.

The text files of the examples used in the book can be found in this link http://www.twc.it/rc/readings.htm

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
+NewSchool #webinar titled #Corpus Confidence by Amy Tate & Emilia Siravo.

Covers #WordandPhrase , #JusttheWord and Google #Ngram

They did a survey of 50 ESL teachers (mostly US and Europe) on knowledge and use of corpus based tools.

22% reported not hearing about corpus based tools this compares with nearly 80% in 2001/2002 of secondary school English teachers (total 248 respondents) in Germany not knowing about corpus linguistics.

So some progress over 12 years or so :)

Another finding from the talk is that 66% are NOT using corpus based tools in their teaching, this compares with  a survey of 600 teachers (mainly university level) in 2012 where 75% WERE using corpus tools in one way or another.

A major reason for no use was lack of time which was also found in the 2012 university based teachers survey.

Also seems Scott Thornbury is going to do a course this summer titled Corpora for language teaching. Any more info on this Scott?

Anyway worthwhile checking the video :)
https://newschool.adobeconnect.com/_a1107314744/p11z2tc19zj/?launcher=false&fcsContent=true&pbMode=normal
ns0:entry.ns0:title: +NewSchool #webinar titled #Corpus Confidence by Amy Tate & Emilia Siravo.

ns0:link.title: +NewSchool #webinar titled #Corpus Confidence by Amy Tate & Emilia Siravo.

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
This is part 3 of  3 videos by the #Virtual #Linguistics #Campus . They use the Lancaster BNCWeb which you need to register as described in video 1.

Video 3 was very useful for me as I found out how to search for pre-fixes and suffixes for verbs i.e. use the VVI part of speech tag - infinitive form of verb.

You can try this in COCA-BYU by using the examples from the video of looking at verb forms with en as a prefix and as a suffix, i.e.:

en*.[v?i*] - http://corpus.byu.edu/bnc/?c=bnc&q=33478109

*en.[v?i*] - http://corpus.byu.edu/bnc/?c=bnc&q=33478118

h/t i_narrator @i_narrator  for video 2 on BNC frequency search
http://youtu.be/hyeCAGzmrVY

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
A new self-study "course" on Corpus Linguistics by Monika Bednarek. I put the course in inverted commas since this flows more like a collection of resources and in fact was orignally "an online information/resource pack on corpus linguistics".

Hence a number of links are external which can get annoying when you click them and you need to wait for a new window to open, this should be labelled in the table of contents as such.

The section on debates has the Chomsky and CL talking point which needs updating in the sense that it is highly debatable whether Chomsky really did "discredit corpus linguistics".

However there are some interesting resources here for example a pdf of why people love corpora [http://www.cambridge.org/elt/resources/appliedlinguistics/corpus/CorpusSurvey.pdf.

Finally as I had only a very cursory look I may be being too critical! :)

h/t HelenCaple ‏@Medlec
http://www.monikabednarek.com/7.html

Hey, I just discovered this community. I've made a useful tool that has indexed millions of hours of audio content (including lots of language learning podcasts) that enables users to search millions of hours of content by phrase or mention.

You can check out the search at https://fluiddata.com

Enjoy!

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
I chanced upon a tool called #DeepDict recently http://gramtrans.com/deepdict/.

The screenshot is the result of looking up the #noun image. It shows you common ways that this word is used (a bit like the #WordSketch feature in #SketchEngine ).

Unfortunately a free account only gives you 10 lookups a day. For 6 months use it wants to charge 21 Euros.

It uses something called a constraint grammar to parse its #corpora ; not sure how this differs from the way WordSketch works which uses #POS tagging. (so far read that #constraint   #grammars are highly accurate and uses dependency networks?)

Anyway a nice tool to explore, even if only 10 times a day :)


update - Just found out free access is limited to 2 weeks! Bugger.

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
A collection of #corpora covering 230 languages! http://corpora.informatik.uni-leipzig.de/

What is also interesting is information on co-occurrences, that is words occurring within the same sentence, in addition to words to the left and right of the search word.

Furthermore there is a #visualization of the co-occurrences, see screenshot for the search term image, which clearly shows two groupings or clusters in use of the word.

The corpora are web based so one can look up contemporary terms.

You can also download the corpora and the #corpus viewer for offline use (windows program).

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
Looking for #authentic audio with pauses, hesitations, ums and errs?  (e.g. read this rationale http://eltmaterialswriter.com/2013/12/03/a-request-for-more-umms-errs-and-what-i-mean-to-say-is/).

Want to help improve the #Lancaster interface to the #BNC audio #corpus ?

Sign up here http://bncweb.lancs.ac.uk/bncwebSignup. If you don't get your automatic email authorization contact Sebastian Hoffman hoffmann at uni-trier dot de. Once signed up head on over to http://bncweb.lancs.ac.uk.

The 1st screenhot shows a keyword analysis comparing spoken BNC to whole BNC (spoken+written). Check those ers and erms :)

The second screenshot shows an example of searching for the word contract. The transcription is in pink at the top, then you see audio player and below the audio player is where you can give feedback on how aligned the audio is with the transcript.

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
I was watching a great #britishcouncil presentation on English as a Lingua Franca, #ELF   (by Katy Simpson Davies & Laura Patsko ) and in part 4 of the talk called Exploiting authentic materials, Laura Patsko  recommends two online resources for recordings of non-native speakers - Speech Accent Archive and International Dialects of English Archive.

Another resource one can use are the 23 recordings available from the #VOICE (Vienna-Oxford International #Corpus of English) - http://www.univie.ac.at/voice/page/index.php.

These recordings can be accessed from the audio tab at the top of the UI screen - see first blue circle in screenshot below.

The 23 recordings are a sample of the total in the corpus, which covers 5 domains:
ED stands for educational, LE for leisure, PB for professional business, PO for professional organization, and PR for professional research and science.

And the following 10 speech events: con (conversation), int (interview), mtg (meeting), pan (panel), prc (press conference), qas (question-answer session), sed (seminar discussion), sve (service encounter), wgd (working group discussion), and wsd (workshop discussion).

So in the screenshot we have a Professional Business recording of a meeting. The number 29 is a number assigned to this text.

In the screenshot label 1 indicates the audio player which can be controlled by rwd, play, fwd, a or the blue indicator, b. Label 2 shows bookmarks you can make for parts that you are interested in. Label 3 shows information on speaker , in this case speaker 1 who has a first language of German. Label 4 shows where you can display the transcript in various modes in this case plain text.

For ideas on how to use such a resource in ELF contexts see full the British Council presentation -http://englishagenda.britishcouncil.org/seminars/practical-ideas-teaching-pronunciation-and-listening-english-lingua-franca-elf-context and the blog site http://elfpron.wordpress.com

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
In an attempt to balance somewhat the bias towards English language #corpora   and demonstrate corpus use in other modern foreign languages #MFL   I am listing here two examples using #chinese   and #french :

1. This is a parallel Chinese corpus that seems to be based on some reading texts rather than on a general reference corpus. If any members here who understand Chinese want to verify this?

http://engres.ied.edu.hk/paraconc/

Seems a very useful teaching tool approach.

2. This is French audio corpora recorded from one town - Orleans. What is great about this is the way a dialogue transcript is highlighted as you play the audio.

Another cool feature is that you can select types of dialogue e.g. meetings, telephone call etc as well as other attributes.

http://eslo.tge-adonis.fr/index.php/pagecorpus/pageaccescorpus

If members know of other language corpora do comment/share.
http://www.parallelcorpus.com

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
So I have been using Word Neighbors (http://wordneighbors.ust.hk) somewhat frequently recently. I was caught out by one of its features so here is a top tip.

Make sure to use both the Words view as well as the Pattern view, this is because the accuracy of the Pattern analysis is not 100%.

I was demonstrating the use of dependent prepositions with the adjective irritated.

In the Pattern view the Adjective + Prep pattern lists irritating to (unexpected!) as most common. However if you look at Verb + Prep pattern this lists irritated by (expected!) as most frequent. Simply switching view to Word view reveals this instantly.
http://wordneighbors.ust.hk

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
Corpora for spelling
Lancaster University has put up a launch page for various #Corpus #Linguistics related #programs (http://corpora.lancs.ac.uk/). One of them which caught my eye is called DICER - Discovery and Investigation of Character Edit Rules, in other words a program to look at #spelling forms. (http://corpora.lancs.ac.uk/dicer/)

They have an analysis of a set of learner corpora (which ones is not given) and the screenshot shows the summary for French native speakers.

1. Edit distance means how far (how many edits) from the standard spelling the variant (mistake) is so here for French speakers the variant is most commonly 1 edit away e.g. scientifice/scientific
2. Is whether the variant is at the start, second, middle, penultimate or end, here the middle position is most common e.g. continiously/continuously
3. Is whether the variant is a deletion, insertion or substitution, the most common here is substitution
4. so if we look here the most common substitution is a hypen (-) for a space (_)
e.g. television-quiz/television_quiz

Variants are also classed into three error types - FS, FM and GADJN. FS - all spelling errors (e.g. parcs/parks), FM - morphological errors (e.g.injustly/unjustly), GADJN - when a general rule of grammar is broken (e.g.Europeans/European).

Not sure how this could be incorporated into a lesson as most spelling errors are not high on teachers’ priority lists (I could be wrong on this though).

Still it is an interesting source of such information, the other native speakers available are German and Spanish.


update: Paul Rayson ‏@perayson reports that they used parts of the ICLE corpus.
ns0:entry.ns0:title: Corpora for spelling

Wow, #corpusmooc keeps on giving, someone has justed posted a Tim Johns program (circa 1994) called Contexts (http://myweb.tiscali.co.uk/wordscape/contexts.zip) which helps learners with several language items using #concordance data as you can seen in the screenshot called Top Level Menu, these are - adjectives, adverbs, body parts, house and garden, nouns, prefixes, prepositions, suffixes, verbs.

As I had been doing prefixes in class today I had a look at the prefixes file which is shown in the following screenshots.

This is an amazing program, I wonder if turning it into a web version would be very difficult?

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
Building your own corpus - TagAnt

Laurence Anthony  does it again bringing difficult to set up programs to the masses with a #tagger called #TagAnt (http://www.antlab.sci.waseda.ac.jp/software.html).

This is based on TreeTagger (http://www.cis.uni-muenchen.de/~schmid/tools/TreeTagger/) which if you follow the link you will see how involved it is to setup!

I ran TagAnt on my multimedia #corpus then used the tagged corpus in AntConc.

Before working with a tagged corpus in AntConc make sure to check all the boxes in the Global Settings>Token Definitions as in Screenshot1.

Also here is a link to list of all the tags that Treetagger uses:
http://courses.washington.edu/hypertxt/csar-v02/penntable.html

Then use the #Clusters tool in AntConc (gleaned from reading the Google groups for AntConc https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/antconc).

For example Screenshot2 shows running a search for verb + noun(inspect Screenshot2 for exact search term). Note that I have set the cluster size to 2.

This shows me that verb + support is quite common:

add support
adds support
adding support
include support
including support
bringing support
drop support
introduces support

I did not notice this when using the non-tagged corpus although support was in the top 60 in the wordlist it would have taken me longer to discern interesting patterns.

Happy Tagging!

p.s. this is continuing my series of diy corpus I started on my blog which you can read here if so interested:http://eflnotes.wordpress.com/tag/build-your-own-corpus/.
ns0:entry.ns0:title: Building your own corpus - TagAnt

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
Some #legal #corpora :

1. The Bononia Legal Corpus [http://corpora.dslo.unibo.it/bolc_eng.html]   - Italian/English, the English subsection approx 59 million words

2. JRC-Acquis [https://ec.europa.eu/jrc/en/language-technologies/jrc-acquis] a multilingual comparable collection of legal texts in 22 different languages focusing on European legislation

3.CorTec [ http://comet.fflch.usp.br/cortec] a scientific-technical collection of texts comparing English and Brazilian Portuguese on commercial law

4.House of Lords Judgments (HOLJ) Extractive Summarisation Corpus [http://www.inf.ed.ac.uk/research/isdd/admin/package?view=1&id=84] is monolingual and includes judicial decisions from the House of Lords

above taken from A corpus-based proposal for the grading of vocabulary teaching materials for the legal english class
[ https://www.academia.edu/9024315/A_corpus-based_proposal_for_the_grading_of_vocabulary_teaching_materials_for_the_legal_English_class]

h/t M.K ‏@usage_based
http://corpora.dslo.unibo.it/bolc_eng.html

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
A new ad-based version of #SKELL Sketch Engine for English Language Learners by Sketch Engine  is out http://skell.sketchengine.co.uk/run.cgi/skell

Came in handy immediately as an issue came up in a class last week with the difference between invoice and bill. I had searched in COCA BYU using the comparison function but did not remember to search by part of speech and so was only thinking of the words as nouns. So the explanation involved the difference between using invoice when related to financial things and bill when related to legislation. Not too convincing an explanation I felt.

However SKELL shows up part of speech as an option automatically after searching, so was reminded that (via the similar words feature) invoice when used as a verb is very similar to bill used as a verb, doh! So reminding me of the potential confusion in the differences between the two words and an added explanation, to the one I mentioned using COCA BYU, that may well help students.

Ah well at least something to show/tell the class next lesson.

h/t KBarrs @corpusloanword ·
http://skell.sketchengine.co.uk/run.cgi/skell

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
this is a nice version of #googlefight for a corpus of conferences and papers in natural language processing and computational linguistics

what is nice is that the results are linked to concordances and other features found in Sketch Engine

an approach like this where results are available in different levels of detail is a good approach to use with corpus based tools

i wonder if the #sketchengine team would consider such an approach  with their other open corpora?

note even if looglefight graph shows 0 hits clicking on bar may take you to some concordances

also seems search word looks at lemmas so you will need to inspect concordances and further filter them in sketchengine if you are after word forms instead
h/t CorporaList
http://looglefight.com/

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
Type your own script (TYOS) aims to help research #scientists develop their writing in English (free registration).

There are 37 texts on letters of complaint, case reports,
articles (biochemistry, dentistry, medicine, cognitive psychology, wine science) letters of request for positions, letters of submission, remarks as a reviewer, reply to answers, abstracts.

Each text has a set of annotatations categorised into:
Verb forms
Discourse linkers
Useful expressions
Interesting grammar points
Vocabulary points
Moves

As the texts were from a French context the annotations contain glosses in French.

Overall a nice resource but the website is clunky to use e.g. you need to click around a lot when looking at annotations.
http://tyos.org/
ns0:entry.ns0:title: Type your own script (TYOS) aims to help research #scientists develop their writing in English (free registration).

ns0:link.title: Type your own script (TYOS) aims to help research #scientists develop their writing in English (free registration).

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
An Arabic #learner #corpus (free registration), the interface is very nice with a useful set of filters.

A great feature is that you can download audio files as well as written texts from your searches.

Info from Corpora List:
--------
Arabic Learner Corpus (ALC)ALC contains a collection of written essays and spoken recordings categorised under two topics: A vacation trip (narrative) and My study interest(discussion) by learners of Arabic in Saudi Arabia in 2012 and 2013. The corpus includes 282,732 words, 29,627 types, and 1,585 materials. It was produced by 942 students from 67 nationalities, and 66 different L1 backgrounds studying at pre-university and university levels. The average length of a text is 178 words.
--------
http://www.alcsearch.com

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
A couple of very nice #corpus based tools - WriteAway http://writeaway.nlpweb.org/ and Linggle http://linggle.com

WriteAway shows examples of the pattern of words so great potential for students to figure out how to structure their sentences.

Linggle is like a souped up just-the-word as it allows you to use part of speech tags and various other filters

h/t Yuichiro Kobayashi @langstat
http://writeaway.nlpweb.org

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
The Compleat Word Lister is a tool originally developed to test the claim that all texts have 50% of words which only occur once (singletons). If true (which the tool shows is not) it would mean that recycling vocabulary in texts for pedagogical purposes would be impossible.

See #LexTutor FB group for further explanation
http://www.lextutor.ca/freq/comp/

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
CQPwebInABox is an #CQP image that you can load using virtualbox. Interesting, will test it. Info from corpus4u.org:
---------
Lancaster University has announced the release of CQPwebInABox. See Andrew Hardie's message below:

Hi everybody,

This is just a quick note to announce the availability of CQPwebInABox – a virtual machine image containing a pre-installed copy of CQPweb.

This will allow you to have your own copy of CQPweb on your own computer, where you can install your own corpora!

The image (1.6GB) can be downloaded here:

https://sourceforge.net/projects/cwb.../CQPwebInABox/

To run it, you will need to install VirtualBox (although I believe other virtualisation tools can also use the same file format, I haven’t yet tested this).

You can get VirtualBox here:

https://www.virtualbox.org/wiki/Downloads

Then “import appliance” from the .ova download.

The virtual machine runs Linux – however, I have set it up in such a way as to make the interface as similar to Windows as possible. So don’t fear the Linux!

I will create some video tutorials & put them on YouTube as soon as I can.

Feedback welcome.

best

Andrew.
-------------

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
Notes for AMALGrAM 2.0 a multi-word expression and semantic tagger

The tagger expects input file to be part of speech (POS) tagged and in a tabbed format. Also there needs to be a space between sentences (https://github.com/nschneid/pysupersensetagger/blob/master/README.md#input-format)

1. So first we need to split the words in a file into separate lines:

tr -s '[[:space:]]' '\n' < file

Note this is for a file already with spaces in between punctuations, for proper tokenisations use the stanford tokenizer:

java edu.stanford.nlp.process.PTBTokenizer file

update been having problems running standford tokenizer so use the following instead:

grep -Eo '\w+|[^\w ]' input.txt

2. POS tag using stanford tagger with -tokenize false flag

java -mx300m -classpath stanford-postagger.jar edu.stanford.nlp.tagger.maxent.MaxentTagger -model models/english-bidirectional-distsim.tagger -tokenize false -textFile file

3. Insert newline after tagged full stop:

sed 's/\._\./&\n/g' file

4. Convert underscores into Tab delimited:

sed 's/_/\t/g' file

5. Finally run file in pysupersensetagger (AMALGrAM)

./sst.sh file


See also: part 2 notes [https://plus.google.com/+MuraNava/posts/7mhfUphECCL]
https://github.com/nschneid/pysupersensetagger/blob/master/README.md#input-format
ns0:entry.ns0:title: Notes for AMALGrAM 2.0 a multi-word expression and semantic tagger

ns0:link.title: Notes for AMALGrAM 2.0 a multi-word expression and semantic tagger

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
Spoken Corpora
Publically available spoken corpora is rarer than the most rare thing you can think of.

A couple of people have been enquiring and my latest look has turned up ORTOLANG Speech and Language Data Repository (SLDR/ORTOLANG) [http://sldr.org/index.php?lang=en&offset=0&nbre=20], hat tip Yutaka Ishii ‏@yishii_0207.

In particular there is the Open ANC [http://sldr.org/voir_depot.php?lang=en&id=770&prefix=sldr] which includes the Charlotte Narrative corpus [http://nsv.uncc.edu/nsv/narratives].

This may be of use to people looking for a 'conversation' corpus and looking to do 'backchannel' language research. (those were the two queries recently)
http://sldr.org/index.php?lang=en&offset=0&nbre=20

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
AntConc Alternatives

Note this a very short comment on some free alternatives to AntConc. I have not tested all the programs fully yet.

There are now a number of free concordance programs that could be used instead of AntConc and I wanted to quickly look at 3 that may be useful for language teachers.

I’ll start with corpkit [http://interrogator.github.io/corpkit/] as it has been widely shared on social media recently. This was originally a set of Python scripts and has now got a graphical user interface (GUI only for Mac OS X at the moment). This is aimed at linguists as it has a number of complex features. Unless you are already very keen on corpus linguistics this software won’t have much utility.

The next program is called CasualConc [https://sites.google.com/site/casualconc/] it is only available for Mac OS X. Although the interface requires bit of a learning curve especially if you are used to AntConc you can get started on using it fairly quickly. If you are so inclined its more advanced features make it stand out such as various statistical calculations, visualizations and experimental features such as a vocabulary profiler.

The last program is MonoconcEsy [https://www.academia.edu/16716002/MonoconcEsy]. This is a windows based program and is very easy to get started with. It does show its age though in terms of the user interface experience.

My personnel recommendation for language teachers would be to have a try of CasualConc if you have Mac OS X otherwise stick to AntConc. If I had a windows system I would try MonoconcEsy more and see how I got on with it. I currently run it on a virtual system which is not very convenient to do regularly.

h/t twitterverse for corpkit, Yasu ‏@casualconc for CasualConc, M.K ‏@usage_based for MonoconcEsy

see also: CorpusExplorer [https://plus.google.com/+MuraNava/posts/doqUJ73266x]

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
Between genres: science journalism and science research

Julie Moore  has a nice post [http://lexicoblog.blogspot.co.uk/2016/01/semi-academic-sources-in-eap-interview.html] on the use of science journalism articles in an EAP settings and how important it is to make students aware that these types of texts are very different to journal research articles.

She points out that part of the appeal of magazine articles on science is that abstracts in journals “are incredibly densely packed and require a certain degree of skill to decode.”

The PLOS (Public Library of Science) website asks authors to write an author summary which is “Distinct from the scientific abstract, the Author Summary is included in the article to make findings accessible to an audience of both scientists and non-scientists."

This presents a possible halfway house for EAP students. The PLOS abstracts are restricted to mainly biology and medical domains and not all papers have author summaries.

One could simply copy paste abstracts and author summaries from the web pages. Or one could semi-automate this.

There is a nice scraper called quickscrape [https://github.com/ContentMine/quickscrape] which allows you to download articles from various journals. Follow the instructions on the github site to set it up and to understand the quickscrape commands. The configuration for plos journals can be modified so that you only need to download the abstracts.

In the journal-scrapers/scrapers/plos.json file modify the file like so:
{
  "url": "plos.*\\.org",
  "elements": {
    "abstract_html": {
      "selector": "(//div[contains(@class,'abstract’)])[2]”
      
    }
      }
}

The number in the above config just downloads the author summary, to download the original abstract change the number to 1.

There seems to be a limitation if you start hitting the journal server too much so be wary of that.

Here are the files for 10 abstracts and 10 author summaries [https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B7FW2BYaBgeiNExJS2FiZzVpYW8]
ns0:entry.ns0:title: Between genres: science journalism and science research

ns0:link.title: Between genres: science journalism and science research

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
COCA search terms for clauses

Although I had known how to find some clauses such as -ing clauses in COCA before, I had trouble finding infinitive clauses and noun phrases. Recently I watched a video about motion charts [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E9Nhex7JSLA] which showed how to find various clauses.

This is relevant for me when teaching reporting verbs in the TOEIC exam. As I was always stumped by what example sentences to come up with for say the verb claim followed by an infinitive clause.

To do this search you use the term [claim] to [v?i*] and we get such examples as claim to be, claim to have, claim to know.

To search for what noun phrases follow claim + that clauses you use [claim] that.[cs*] * [n*]. We get example such as claim that the state, claim that the U.S., claim that the President.

As I mentioned -ing clauses are straight forward to find you just add [v?g*] to the end of your search.

For full clauses you can add [p*] [v*] to the search, so for the claim example we could use [claim] [p*] [v*] and get results such as claimed he was, claimed it was, claimed he had.

The above search terms are also useful to get examples of causative verbs that are also required in the TOEIC.
ns0:entry.ns0:title: COCA search terms for clauses

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
Exploring audio clip tools using the BNC spoken corpus

There are now a number of audio corpus interfaces available that allow you to get examples of spoken English. These vary from Movies and TV shows such as Playphrase (http://playphrase.me) and Yarn (http://getyarn.io/yarn-popular), h/t Sandy Millin ‏@sandymillin, to Youtube videos such as Youglish (http://youglish.com/) and Divii (http://www.divii.org/).

A question arises as to what search terms to use, i.e. what are frequent terms that we could use in class? In order to get a list of frequent terms one can use the Spokes interface to the Spoken BNC (British National Corpus).[http://pelcra.clarin-pl.eu/SpokesBNC/#explore/kp/0/100]

It has a feature that lists all the common formulae such as the following top 3:
thank you very much
i don't know
isn't it

One now has a nice base in order to explore the tools mentioned initially. Of course one must bear in mind that the BNC is dated so current conversational English will not be represented well.

Thanks to Cara Leopold @eltinfrance for prompting this note.
ns0:entry.ns0:title: Exploring audio clip tools using the BNC spoken corpus

ns0:link.title: Exploring audio clip tools using the BNC spoken corpus

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
BootCat Top Tip
If you use BootCat here is a command to help you separate the collected corpus into individual files using the CURRENT URL line as a separator in a regex:

awk '/CURRENT URL/{g++} { print $0 > g".txt"}' corpus.txt

Be careful when copy pasting this command into your command line that the apostrophe ' is straight and not curly.

related:
BootCat custom URL: [https://eflnotes.wordpress.com/2014/10/08/building-your-own-corpus-bootcat/]
BootCat seeding: [https://plus.google.com/+MuraNava/posts/8JjUVKyA8FE]

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
Email corpora
1) The most famous is no doubt the ENRON corpus e.g. [https://www.cs.cmu.edu/~enron/] or the ENRON Sent corpus [http://savethevowels.org/enronsent/]

2) There is the Business Letter Corpus [http://www.someya-net.com/concordancer/], shame interface to this is limited.

3) British Columbia Conversation Corpora (BC3): Email corpus [https://www.cs.ubc.ca/cs-research/lci/research-groups/natural-language-processing/bc3.html#email]

4) SPAM and non-SPAM email datasets [http://csmining.org/index.php/data.html]

5) Hilary Clinton email archive by Wikileaks [https://wikileaks.org/clinton-emails/].

6) US Democratic National Convention email archive [https://wikileaks.org/dnc-emails/].

Thanks to Laura Adele Soracco for prompting this post.

related:
Enron corpus primer tutorial [https://plus.google.com/+MuraNava/posts/eMuCSNRPVRt]

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
Comparing modal verbs in COCA

This arose from a student query in class.

One can easily compare words that are similar in COCA fairly easily. For example comparing the modal verbs will and shall gives quite a nice results screen when the collocates are the verbs following the modals - [http://corpus.byu.edu/coca/?c=coca&q=52703898]. The results show that will is about 52 times as frequent as shall, and that the verb collocates of shall seem quite formal.

Comparing may and might does not give as stark a difference [http://corpus.byu.edu/coca/?c=coca&q=52703967] though some patterns are detectable for example the use of might have for speculation and that may is maybe more formal.

To investigate whether may is more formal we can use the chart feature to check genre/register distribution. The distribution for might is balanced with maybe a peak in fiction register [http://corpus.byu.edu/coca/?c=coca&q=52704091], however for may we can clearly see dominant use in the academic register [http://corpus.byu.edu/coca/?c=coca&q=52704056].
ns0:entry.ns0:title: Comparing modal verbs in COCA

The Corpus of Multilingual Opinion Essays by College Students (MOECS)
From the site:
The Corpus of Multilingual Opinion Essays by College Students (MOECS) is a collection of essays by college students. This is open to any researchers only for a research purpose. The corpus includes essays of English (collected in Australia including international students with English as a first language background), Japanese, Korean, and Taiwanese first language (L1), and English of Japanese learners, Japanese of English learners, Japanese of Korean learners, and Japanese of Taiwanese learners.

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
Multi-word searches in BNC2014 and BNC1994
Multiword searches in the spoken BNC2014 can be done by:
(?longest) [pos=".*\d\d"]+

and to look for a particular length e.g. 5 words:
[pos=".*5\d"]{5}

For spoken BNC1994 use following terms:
(+)+

Note the list used to tag multi-words can be found here: [http://ucrel.lancs.ac.uk/bnc2sampler/ditto.htm]
h/t Andrew Hardie @HardieResearch
ns0:entry.ns0:title: Multi-word searches in BNC2014 and BNC1994

ns0:link.title: Multi-word searches in BNC2014 and BNC1994

New 14 billion iWeb corpus at BYU
Not yet launched officially ; )

What is new here is that the downloaded web sites were systematically collected unlike most web corpora which are very random and noisy.

Very nice features for the top 60,000 words e.g. a comprehensive word profiler; topics; a SketchEngine "wordsketch" like feature for collocations and clusters; words associated with particular websites; a related words feature; search by syllable stress.

And total word count is about 14 billion! (22 million web pages from nearly 95,000 different websites)

Remember you read it here first : )
https://corpus.byu.edu/iweb/

ns0:link.title: New 14 billion iWeb corpus at BYU

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
Hi Corpus Linguists. Help needed with EFCAMDAT, please!

I'm interested in how people use wh- phrases after prepositions (e.g. ...interested IN HOW people use wh-...). I've used BNC to analyse native speaker/proficient-language user texts. Now I'm using EFCAMDAT to look at how students may avoid it (as a result of oversimplification in ELT materials etc.) and I want to compare the corpora's frequencies.

But I've hit a couple of problems: 1) In the Add PoS: drop down menu, prepositions are lumped in with subordinate clause conjunctions (why?); 2) If I make the query about wh- adverbs, determiners or pronouns used as the object of a preposition, e.g. [(pos="WP.*") &  (dg-hpos="pobj")], then I get 0 matches returned (at least from the level 7 scripts I'm currently searching) which surely can't be right, can it?.

Very specific question, I know, but any ideas, pointers, general help would be much appreciated.
ns0:entry.ns0:title: Hi Corpus Linguists. Help needed with EFCAMDAT, please!

ns0:link.title: Hi Corpus Linguists. Help needed with EFCAMDAT, please!

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
Ce site présente 710 pièces de théâtre et spectacles de 1610 à 1802, en vers (plus de 630 000 vers) et en prose à consulter ou éditer comportant des fonctions de recherche et de statistiques de vocabulaire ou sur les rimes. Vous pouvez aussi rechercher les occurences d'un mot dans un texte. De Du Ryer à Voltaire, en passant par Corneille, Molière, Racine, Dancourt, Marivaux : le corpus est accompagné de plus cents textes polémiques ou théoriques encadrant le corpus dans son contexte historique. Les pièces peuvent être comparées deux à deux dans leur structure globale, soit avec leur vocabulaire.
http://www.theatre-classique.fr/

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
This dictionary is based on the 100 million word British National Corpus.

www.ozdic.com brings you a completely new type of dictionary that will help the learners of English to write and speak natural-sounding English. 

Collocations - common word combinations such as 'bright idea' or 'talk freely' - are the essential building blocks of natural-sounding English.

The dictionary contains over 150,000 collocations for nearly 9,000 headwords. The dictionary shows all the words that are commonly used in combination with each headword: nouns, verbs, adjectives, adverbs, and prepositions as well as common phrases. 

Internet searches were made to ensure the most up-to-date usage for fast changing areas of language such as computing.
http://www.ozdic.com/

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
Corpus-based exercise formats
Using Corpora to Help Teach Difficult-to-distinguish English Words (2013) by Dilin Liu, section 3 gives a nice format for #teachers to present #corpus derived (from #COCA ) exercises.

Ex1 type is a fill in the gap, Ex2 is a replace keeping original sentence meaning and Ex3 is an error detection one with a translation of corrected sentence.

See the following which is extracted from exercises on differentiating the synonyms incorrectly and wrongly from page 37 and 38:

(1) Exercise 1: Decide whether incorrectly or wrongly fills in each blank better semantically; write either if you believe either adverb works equally well.

a. The United Nations TV had --------- identified Mr. Smith as the ambassador (either)

(2) Exercise 2: Decide whether incorrectly or wrongly or either adverb may replace each underlined word while keeping the original meaning and tone of the sentence.

a. It has been found that some of the prisoners were unjustly convicted. (wrongly)

(3) Exercise 3. Some of the underlined uses of incorrectly and wrongly are inappropriate. Identify and correct them. Then translate the sentences into Korean.

a. I incorrectly identified Brit Hume as being located at the White House right now. (correct)

Some of the sentences have been adapted e.g.:

sentence clauses into full sentences: The tape was acquired from United Nations TV which had incorrectly identified the ambassador —> The United Nations TV had incorrectly/wrongly identified Mr. Smith as the ambassador;

filling in ellipsis: David Hilliard's title --> David Hilliard's job title.

more or less wholesale rewrites: Some of the prisoners USA TODAY contacted -- and their lawyers -- were stunned to find out that they were imprisoned for something that turned out not to be a federal crime —> It has been found that some of the prisoners were unjustly convicted.

The article does not mention whether sentences were changed to suit student level and/or readibility.

http://journal.kate.or.kr/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/kate_68_3_2.pdf
ns0:entry.ns0:title: Corpus-based exercise formats

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
Very neat summary by Anthony Schmidt of #corpus analysis of #errors by French learners of English. The study does make a good point about effects of focusing on sentence vs larger discourse on verb tense choice by these French students.

Although the two corpora used were the same size no information is given in the study on whether the data came from the same number of students. I would imagine that analysis of individual errors would have complemented the information from the averaging of errors over the two corpora?

The discussion in part 5 of the study was useful to me as a teacher in France as it outlines some issues learners here have when choosing #verb tenses.

http://www.anthonyteacher.com/blog/researchbites/research-bites-grammar-beyond-the-sentence?utm_content=buffer346d0&utm_medium=social&utm_source=twitter.com&utm_campaign=buffer

h/t Leo Selivan 
http://www.anthonyteacher.com/blog/researchbites/research-bites-grammar-beyond-the-sentence?utm_content=buffer346d0&utm_medium=social&utm_source=twitter.com&utm_campaign=buffer

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
Bigger is not necessarily better
It was interesting to read that a large #corpus such as #COCA -BYU can actually bias the language collected.  Before I go on how do you think a large corpus can bias the data?





This paper - On Using Corpus Frequency, Dispersion and Chronological Data to Help Identify Useful Collocations [http://www.smartsmart.org/researchsample.pdf] reports that a lot of the collocations it found were related to food and cooking. That is because the magazines and newspapers used by COCA regularly had recipes.

Another bias the study discusses is with the spoken section of COCA which uses a lot of television news and talk shows hence the language reflects those of newscasters and talk show hosts.

Finally the study highlights the lack of a specific business sub corpus such as there is for academic langauge, at the moment business language is spread across spoken, magazine and newspaper sources but not with particularly high frequencies.
http://www.smartsmart.org/researchsample.pdf
ns0:entry.ns0:title: Bigger is not necessarily better

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
Following on the queries about which #corpus tools are used, Chris #Tribble has kindly shared a paper titled Teaching and language corpora: Perspectives from a personal journey [https://googledrive.com/host/0B7FW2BYaBgeiTWRkVS1RMXViNlE/13Tribblefinal_rev.pdf] from a forthcoming volume.

It comprises a section on the history of corpus tools in language teaching with citations to seminal work by community member John Higgins . And a section summarising the 2012 #survey of Corpora in ELT, the screenshot shows responses to most useful tool question (and to answer our original question it seems amongst teachers Wordsmith Tools is the favoured offline tool). A total of 560 people answered the survey from some 63 countries.

There is a lot of other interesting information in the paper, go check it out.

Also if you want to look at a brief history of computerised corpus tools have a look at: http://timemapper.okfnlabs.org/muranava/history-of-computerised-corpus-tools
https://googledrive.com/host/0B7FW2BYaBgeiTWRkVS1RMXViNlE/mostuseful-corpustool.png

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
Paper [https://www.academia.edu/3631516/Computer-Mediated_Collocation_Resources_for_Exploring_Word_Choice_in_English_Academic_Writing] describing various #onlinetools students can use to help with #collocation choices. It has a very nice table assessing the tools according to the following six questions (using example of extent):

(1) I want to explore extent. What are some of its collocates?
(2) Is big extent a collocation? I want to just type it in; if it’s not a
collocation, there should be 0 hits.
(3) Is the correct collocation big extent or large extent? I want to
search two phrases at the same time.
(4) What adjectives commonly precede extent?
(5) What adjectives commonly precede extent that mean something
like big extent?
(6) It’s on the tip of my tongue! I want to do a wildcard search.

It makes the emininently sensible suggestion of getting students to use multiple tools to triangulate searches.

h/t M.K @usage_based

Is Intuition as Good as Corpus Frequency for Selecting Vocabulary?
An ELT Research Bites summary by Anthony Schmidt. To corpus kool-aid drinkers that intuition can match corpus frequency may be surprising : ). Though research in this area seems to have been saying this for a while.

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
There are some interesting analysis happening in the first practical activity 1.26 in #corpusmooc .

I used the Lextutor Text Compare feature (http://www.lextutor.ca/text_lex_compare/) and screenshotted the first 30 odd results. (I combined corpus files using command line cat and copy pasted into lextutor text compare).

You can see immediately differences in proper nouns - names and places between the Brown corpus and the LOB corpus.

Common noun differences also appear - e.g. gyro in Brown, grid in LOB. There are also some artifacts e.g. pc in LOB only appears once when using antconc and not 38 times as in screenshot. The word number seems to be an artifact as well since there are about the same in Brown as in LOB.
ns0:entry.ns0:title: There are some interesting analysis happening in the first practical activity 1.26 in #corpusmooc .

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
#corpusmooc 1.23 Laurence Anthony near end of video types in a #regex command but it is not really visible (unless you really squint and listen as I did!).

I think the command is \br[a-z]*?t\b

\b - is beginning of word boundary
r - is start character of word
[a-z] - means any letter from a to z
* - zero or more characters
? - non greedy search (not sure what this means)
t- end character of word
\b - is end of word boundary

So the above will find all words beginning with r and ending with t.

update - you can switch to HD view in video player settings, doh!

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
Formatting wordlists for AntConc
#AntConc   needs #wordlists in the order rank, frequency, word but most wordlists you can find on the net are in the order rank, word, frequency.

I have tried using Excel to change the columns around but with big wordlists that takes a while!

What is even simpler is to use command line, if you are on Windows you can download #Cygwin http://www.cygwin.com/ to get #command line tools.

I am using OSX which already has such tools.

The command you need is:

awk - F'[\t| ]' '{print $1,$3,$2}' OFS="\t" frequency_list_BE06.txt > AntConcBE06List.txt

- the - F switch tells awk to look at tabs (\t) or spaces (note the hypen should have no space between it and the letter F, G+ now seems to use hypen as strikethrough markup!)
- the print command says to swap column 2 with column 3
- the OFS command tells to output file in tab form
- frequency_listBE06 is my input wordlist
- AntConcBE06List is my new AntConc friendly word list

Note that before loading the new reference wordlist you also need to set the TokenDefinitions in Global Settings in AntConc by ticking all the boxes there i.e. Letter, Number, Punctuation, Symbol, Mark
ns0:entry.ns0:title: Formatting wordlists for AntConc

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
UCREL semantic tagger
#corpusmooc introduced me to the #UCREL #semantic tagger which you can find here http://ucrel.lancs.ac.uk/usas/

i apologize in advanced for bringing a #sugatamitra related post but hear me out!

i thought the #iatefl   mitra debates would be a nice way to get to know about semantic tagging. so i ran the texts i collected on Wednesday 09 April from the net (note i only did a minimal of cleaning up text, so  some duplicates for example are in my current corpus) through the #lancaster tagger.

note also i have texts divided into original blog posts and texts of comments to the blog posts.

the graphic you see are from the comments to the blog posts and is a way for me to get my head around what could be likely concordances to investigate manually - the words in brackets in the figure labels are potential keywords, the ~ sign represents the most interesting collocation.

let me know what you think, is this a good way to pre-analyse a semantically tagged corpus or not?
ns0:entry.ns0:title: UCREL semantic tagger

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
Prize Draw corpusmooc 2015 round 3

To mark the third round of #corpusmooc by Lancaster university which starts on 28 September 2015,  the G+ CL Community is putting up a prize draw for the book Discovering English with SketchEngine by James Thomas .

To enter you should be enrolled on #corpusmooc and answer the following question:

According to the BYU-COCA interface what is the 9th most common adjective that goes with the noun prize? Use the default window size of 4 words to left and 4 words to right.

In the case of a tie there will be a qualifying question.

Post your answers in this thread. Postage will be included in prize.

To find out a bit about the book have a read of this - https://eflnotes.wordpress.com/2015/06/14/discovering-english-with-sketchengine-james-thomas-interview/

*Note this prize draw is not officially associated with the #corpusmooc or Lancaster University.*

Good Luck!

There have been some interesting links shared by #corpusmoocers which members may find of interest, note this is just a sample of what I find interesting, at the close of the mooc I will put up the full list I am collecting.

CorpusMooc 2016 round 4 Blog Posts
CorpusMooc 2016 has kicked off and time to collect participants blog posts : )
First one on the radar is by Marc Jones
#CorpusMOOC Week 1 notes
[https://freelanceteacherselfdevelopment.wordpress.com/2016/09/27/corpusmooc-week-1-notes/]

Marc asks if certain frequent language items are acquired later rather than earlier. No doubt, and not easy to answer but an important point is raised that we can't solely depend on frequency when deciding what to teach based on corpus descriptions.

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
Corpusmooc 2016 round 4 aids
Here I will occasionally put up helpers/explainers/aids related to queries people have had on the #corpusmooc .

For example there were a number of questions about collocation statistics so I knocked up a chart based on a video and one of the readings - Identifying Collocations [https://magic.piktochart.com/output/16856740-identify_collocations]

I did some similar charts for previous corpusmoocs you can look up in the corpusmooc section.

Another set of queries was about distinguishing collocations from colligations (see previous corpusmooc for a related chart), this time round found a nice example from John Sinclair:

For example, the English letter string second can be claimed to have two primary meanings based on results of a collocation analysis: (i) ‘next to the first’ when it is used together with words such as the, world, war, year, child and wife, and (ii) ‘a unit of time’ when it is preceded by words such as per, radians and cycles. In addition to being attracted to different lexical contexts, the two primary meanings of second also prefer different grammatical contexts: second as ‘next to the first’ is often a part of a definite noun phrase, while second as ‘a unit of time’ can be usually found in an indefinite noun phrase (Sinclair 1991: 107). Hence, the collocational preferences of the two senses correlate with the colligational preferences.

which was cited in the following pdf - [http://pubman.mpdl.mpg.de/pubman/item/escidoc:2304786:2/component/escidoc:2304785/Collocation%20and%20colligation.pdf]

Hope these are of use : )
https://magic.piktochart.com/output/16856740-identify_collocations

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
When is Open not open? FutureLearn MOCS
The new #corpusmooc seems to be time-limited (8 weeks + 14 days) unless you cough up 34(+shipping) Euros. Reading up on the FutureLearn site they state that:
"it is therefore for partners to determine the appropriate licensing for this course content."
I noticed a number of courses have been doing this recently so it seems to be a default position encouraged by FutureLearn?
Has Lancaster University actively agreed to this or simply going along with such a default position?
Some impact is mitigated by the public access made by Lancaster Uni to taxpayer supported material such as #lancsbox (concordancer software).
I don't want to come across too much as, what some people disparagingly call, a "freetard" and the economics of running online education has many challenges. However, this FutureLearn position certainly jars up against the original philosophies of MOOCS - massive OPEN online course.
Time to look to alternative linguistic MOOCS? such as Virtual Linguistic Campus [https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaMpov1PPVXGcKYgwHjXB3g]

See also:
Other noteworthy developments in #corpusmooc [https://plus.google.com/u/0/+MuraNava/posts/foVTzqTF9a1]

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
BootCat Seeding

There could be some disappointment with #corpusmooc week 4 billed as building your own corpus. The lectures are more of a general discussion of corpus building along with very useful lectures on the CLAWS part of speech tagging and USAS semantic tagging.

In my opinon a section on the web as a corpus would have been good. For example the use of #BootCat . You can read about how to use BootCat here - http://bootcat.sslmit.unibo.it/?section=home. What I would like to note is the process of finding good seed words.

How BootCat works is this:

1.seed (words) - e.g. you can use keywords derived from comparing a sample corpus (that you build manually) to a reference corpus
2. tuples - the seed words are combined, default is three so for example if seeds are one, two, three, four, five (you need min of 5 seed words); a tuple could be one, two, four , default no. of tuples is 10
3. collect urls - collect urls that contain these tuples, you need to go through this carefully to ensure the text is what you want; BootCat helpfully links to the urls for you to check but of course if you have a lot of URLs it is a time consuming process; you can alleviate this somewhat by specifying domains to leave out of the url collection stage
4. build corpus - build corpus with the collected urls

If you are not satisfied with the resulting corpus you can redo BootCat process using say keywords and/or n-grams from the (unsatisfying) corpus to build a new BootCat corpus. You can of course keep repeating this.

When I was looking to build web design related corpora the results I was getting were disappointing. Then I hit upon the idea of using already existing categories from A List Apart, a well known site for web designers. They have a topics section, so for example one of their top level topics of Design includes Brand Identity, Graphic Design, Layout & Grids, Mobile/Multidevice, Responsive Design,Typography & Web Fonts.

So I used these as seed words and the resulting corpus was much better, I intend to do a similar approach to build corpora reflecting two other A List Apart top level topics of Code and User Experience.

Apparently there is a new version of BootCat coming with some neat new features.

FYI if you already have a website that you want to collect texts from have a read of my post here - http://eflnotes.wordpress.com/2013/03/06/building-your-own-corpus-textstat-antconc/


see also - BootCat Custom URL [https://eflnotes.wordpress.com/2014/10/08/building-your-own-corpus-bootcat/]
http://bootcat.sslmit.unibo.it/?section=home
ns0:entry.ns0:title: BootCat Seeding

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
Hi there! I'm a current MA student in Durham University, new to the community, and looking for advice on what areas of research I could delve into using corpora. I've been interested in corpora since last term and have to hand in a dissertation proposal next week.

 I was wondering if it might be worth looking into the language presented in coursebooks and comparing them with corpora data to see if the coursebook language is representative of language that is actually used. 

OR if it might be more useful to work on a learner's corpora here at the university based off of international students' texts to help analyse supposed written errors . Perhaps this could provide a look into whether common errors are made or if what looks like errors are really just a different word choices that represent the writer's perceptions? 

Basically I was hoping to use corpora in my research but haven't been able to really narrow it down to a research question and don't want to go into something that has been overly researched already. Any feedback or advice would be greatly appreciated!

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
A snapshot of how I work with #concordances :

I am currently trying to set-up a quick exercise on #multimedia   related words.

I have my corpus loaded in AntConc. The cleaned-up corpus admittedly took me a few hours to set-up (I may detail that sometime).

So now I have just run the keyword list function and am picking out some relevant words.

For example blog scores highly and so I looked at the concordances of blog.

I then sort the concordance lines one word to the left and see that the patterns with blog fall into 3 groups, possesive pronoun - my blog; with article - a blog; and as verb - I blog. (I attach the sorted concordance lines for blog).

I am now going through those groups to pick out some suitable ones where the surrounding words are appropriate to my students.

I will then use these sentences in a gap fill asking students to find the missing word.

I'll repeat this for other relevant/interesting multi-media words.

Let me know if you have any questions.

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
Wrangling regular expressions and commandeering the command line

At some point when dealing with texts you will have to use the #commandline   and #regularexpressions   as it makes life much easier, although of course there is a steep learning curve.

Needs must and I recently bit the bullet and did my first #regex commands.

I am working with text from The Setup http://usesthis.com/ - a series of interviews which poses 4 simple questions about the equipment setup that people use in their work.

Now this website is great not only for the interesting interviews but for the fact that since the project is hosted on github one can very easily have a copy of all the interviews (i.e. you need a github account, then you can copy(fork) the project and download files).

Once you have the text files they need a little cleaning since the words which are linked are given in square brackets and the http link is put into round brackets e.g. :

I'm [Alex Payne](http://al3x.net/ "Alex's website."). I go by [al3x](http://twitter.com/al3x "Alex's Twitter account.") around the Interwho. I work at [Twitter](http://twitter.com/ "Micro-blogging FTW.") in San Francisco as their [API](http://apiwiki.twitter.com/ "The Twitter API Wiki.") Lead.

I want to remove only the square brackets [ ] and everything between the round brackets, including the round brackets.

A command for removing only the square brackets using the #sed   command is:

sed -i.bak 's/[ ] [ ]//g' file.txt

The -i.bak is really two commands the -i means replace the original file with the results of the sed program (keeping both the unmatched text and the matched text) and .bak means make a backup of the original file.

The 's/[ ][ ]//g' is the interesting part as this contains the regular expression.

The normal structure of the substitute sed s command is
's/regex/replacement/g'

In this case the characters I want is [ and ], but since [ is already a command i.e. [abc] will match a or b or c,  you can put the closing square bracket first and then the opening square bracket i.e. [ ] [ ] will match ] or [ which is the same as matching [ or ].

The replacement is simply a blank. The g means match all occurences of the regex pattern.

Now I want to delete the round brackets and everything in between the round brackets the command is :

sed -i.bak2 's/([^( )]*)//g' file.txt

Notice I called the new backup bak2 so I can distinguish easily between the results of the two commands. It is possible to combine commands but not figured that out yet!

The regex looks for the opening bracket (.

Then anything between that is not an opening bracket or close bracket, the caret ^ means not the following character i.e. not ( or ).

The star means match zero or more of such characters which are not an opening bracket or closing bracket.

Then finally match a closing bracket ).

Not sure how useful my particular example will be to people here but I wanted to highlight the fact that understanding regular expressions and using the command line saves a lot of time.

For example at the time of writing this there are 395 interview files, imagine having to open them up in a text editor and doing find and replace! In the command line it is a simple case of using unix wildstar on the text, in my case 2*.txt as the files are labelled year-month-day-nameofinterviewee.txt

There are numerous resources on using regex and sed command online; I learnt a bit because I had the need not to go through 395 text files!

Thanks for reading.

Questions welcome.
http://usesthis.com/
ns0:entry.ns0:title: Wrangling regular expressions and commandeering the command line

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
A common problem with using #corpora like #COCA is the amount of surrounding words that can cause problems for students; of course one way around that is to choose carefully the concordances and/or modify them.

Another route is to use a #gradedreader #corpus ,the lextutor site provides some graded readers here http://www.lextutor.ca/conc/graded/.

They total to about 1.3 million words so not a shabby corpus size. :)

The lextutor graded reader interface doesn't allow wildcard searches (though you could use the main lextutor concordancer), downloading files and using #antconc will give you more options and control.

You can of course copy paste/download each file by hand but a much quicker way is to use the wget command (this is standard on Linux and OSX and separate download available for Windows).

In a terminal first build a file of the URLs from the graded reader site:
cat > listofurls.txt

Then run:
wget -i listofurls.txt

If you are not familiar/comfortable with running command lines let me know to get a copy of the texts.

So for example I was looking for sentences with the word contract (for my TOEIC class).

As you can see from the 1st screenshot the word contract comes from a level 5 text which is B2 or upper intermediate; this still produces a relatively “simple” sentence  with some nice collocations e.g.  In our business, contracts are made and cancelled routinely.

With less specialized items you can get more range of levels e.g. advice (the 2nd screenshot):
a level 3 text gives - She always gave us good advice.

A graded reader corpus is also a way for students to get into concordances; for some info on whether a graded corpus is ‘authentic’ see "Can a graded reader corpus provide ‘authentic’ input?" by Rachel Allan (2008) https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B7FW2BYaBgeiVmxpeGlyNk5EWmc/edit?usp=sharing


Related - COCA-BYU's Fiction-Juvenile section [https://plus.google.com/+MuraNava/posts/CWQdHv7dzHm]
ns0:entry.ns0:title: A common problem with using #corpora like #COCA is the amount of surrounding words that can cause problems for...

ns0:link.title: A common problem with using #corpora like #COCA is the amount of surrounding words that can cause problems for...

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
An idea to use very short scenes from films as a way to #teach   #corpus use #literacy .

A #dialogue from the latest Hobbit movie features the word jiffy. Ask students to listen to the scene and transcribe the dialogue. After some listens they may get the following:

Thorin: Balin, can you still mix a flash flame?
Balin: Aye, it’ll only take a jiffy, c’mon
Dwalin: We don’t have a jiffy.

Ask students what they think jiffy means?
Then ask them to go to #COCA and enter the following search:

it 'll only take a *

they should get the following:

IT 'LL ONLY TAKE A MINUTE
IT 'LL ONLY TAKE A SECOND
IT 'LL ONLY TAKE A FEW
IT 'LL ONLY TAKE A MOMENT
IT 'LL ONLY TAKE A COUPLE

ask them what kind of word they see in the list; ask them to click on few and couple to see what follows them;

then see if it holds true for the following search:

it will only take a *

additionally tell students:

1)that an asterisk represents any single word, ask them to add another asterisk to first search term

2)punctuation marks need to include a space when they are in the search term

3)to combine both ‘ll and will in one search use the pipe character |

(http://corpus.byu.edu/coca/?c=coca&q=27583618)
http://corpus.byu.edu/coca/?c=coca&q=27583632

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
reposting this as G+ has lost it, this losing of posts is getting tiresome!

An idea to use very short scenes from films as a way to raise awareness of #corpus use #literacy .

A dialogue from the latest #Hobbit movie features the word jiffy. Ask students to listen to the scene and transcribe the dialogue. After some listens they may get the following:

Thorin: Balin, can you still mix a flash flame?
Balin: Aye, it’ll only take a jiffy, c’mon
Dwalin: We don’t have a jiffy.


Ask students what they think jiffy means?
Then ask them to go to COCA and enter the following search:

it 'll only take a *

they should get the following:

IT 'LL ONLY TAKE A MINUTE
IT 'LL ONLY TAKE A SECOND
IT 'LL ONLY TAKE A FEW
IT 'LL ONLY TAKE A MOMENT
IT 'LL ONLY TAKE A COUPLE

ask them what kind of word follows; ask them to click on few and couple to see what follows them;

then see if it holds true for the search

it will only take a *

additionally tell students:
1)that an asterisk represents any single word, ask them to add another asterisk to first search term

2)punctuation marks need to include a space when they are in the search term

3)to combine both ‘ll and will use the pipe character |
http://corpus.byu.edu/coca/?c=coca&q=27583530
http://corpus.byu.edu/coca/?c=coca&q=27583530

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
I would suggest , even though I have no evidence, that open access corpora such as #BYU #COCA have single-handedly done more to encourage corpus use than anything else in recent times.

As members of this community I would think that we would want to see this kind of development. If something is made a commons people make use of it and who knows what opportunities have been lost to closed off corpora.

So it was with interest I saw a tweet that #cambridgeuniversity Press  are looking to build a new spoken corpus (http://www.networxrecruitment.com/Jobs/Advert/46522?FromSearch=False). I enquired as to whether this corpus would be open to the public, their answer :

No, I'm afraid out Cambridge English Corpus is only for use by Cambridge University Press.

Notice the typo, out for our; so this is our corpus because we transacted with you for a set price (18pounds) and now that commodity is our property that you can’t access unless you transact with us for another set price (?pounds).

Unfortunately the same holds true for other tax-payer funded academic institutions where for example learner corpora are under pay licenses.

Do we need to co-operate with such practices? Are there possibilities to agitate for change? Do you disagree with me?

Hmm well that did not turn into too much of a rant.

Here’s the email to the corpus project if you feel like enquiring yourself: corpus@cambridge.org
http://www.networxrecruitment.com/Jobs/Advert/46522?FromSearch=False

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
There is a nice list of ways of #counting written up by one Heather Froehlich ‏@heatherfro. This is good way to introduce things a computer can do with a corpus before more 'technical' words like #collocation, #clusters etc.:

Ways of Counting
Words
Kinds of words
Words with certain features
Words without certain features
Words that show up a lot
Words that show up very rarely
Words that are there
Words that aren’t there
Words that appear more in one set compared to another
set
Words that appear less in one set compared to another
set
Words likely to be near other words
Words unlikely to be near other words
Words that make recognizable phrases
Words that do not make recognizable phrases

She lists some others which are more suited to a humanities audience as she is a humanities scholar.

You can find her slides here:http://hfroehlich.files.wordpress.com/2014/01/northwestern-2014-new-world-of-words.pdf
http://hfroehlich.files.wordpress.com/2014/01/northwestern-2014-new-world-of-words.pdf

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
Dogme and manual concordancing

So I was working 1-to-1with a student on listening to Scottish accents using a recording taken from the International Dialects of English Archive.

It was a simple procedure of listening to extracts of the recording a few times to identify what he could, doing a number of micro-listens, then turning to the transcript to check.

After this we went through the transcript to look at any interesting lexis. My student noticed that the speaker was using a lot of 'guess'. I had not noticed this as I was still looking for parts related to decoding issues.

Whilst we were having a discussion on why the speaker was using guess and how, it struck me to try a manual #concordancing of the word guess from the text.

The photo is the result. I explained to the student that we can call this a concordance and that it helps us look at how words work - in this case use of pronoun I, co-occurrence with so, but, and positions at start or middle of sentence.

I also took the opportunity to mention http://www.just-the-word.com/ as a way to see more uses of concordances.

So I claim this as a use of #dogme concordancing. :)

For an interesting read of blackboard concordancing or hand concordancing have a read of this report of two Spanish teachers in France - Corpus work with ordinary teachers: Data-driven learning activities by Henry Tyne - https://www.academia.edu/1474616/Corpus-work_with_ordinary_teachers_Data-driven_learning_activities
ns0:entry.ns0:title: Dogme and manual concordancing

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
#Phrasal #verbs duh duh duh! Strikes real fear in many learners' hearts and trepidation to many teachers - especially what phrasal verbs to teach?

One reference I found is - Pointing Out Frequent Phrasal Verbs: A #Corpus -Based Analysis by Dee Gardener & Mark Davies (2007) http://203.72.145.166/tesol/tqd_2008/VOL_41_2.pdf

They point out that the four most common adverb particles are out, up, down, back. This can help learners and teachers identify phrasal verbs. They go on to list the 20 most common lexical verbs. The study is based on the British National Corpus (BNC), what if one is looking for say business phrasal verbs?

This is where the great #BYU #COCA interface comes in handy, we can easily search by sections.

So for example looking at the lexical verb GO ,which is the number one ranked verb in the study, plus the part of speech (POS) adverb particle and choosing MAG(azine):Financial and comparing it to all of the MAGAZINE genre we see GO under as being 5 times more common in MAG:Financial, this holds true when comparing NEWS(paper):Money to NEWSPAPER.

http://corpus.byu.edu/coca/?c=coca&q=27962547

Further when comparing MAG:Financial to NEWS:Money we see GO along as being twice as common in MAG:Financial as in NEWS:Money

http://corpus.byu.edu/coca/?c=coca&q=27962581

One can do similar searches with the other lexical verbs given in the study. This is a way then to draw up a list of interesting business phrasal verbs.

The other problem is then of course how to tackle the different meanings of a phrasal verb?!

See also:
[https://plus.google.com/+MuraNava/posts/hXPEBYURsKG]
[https://plus.google.com/+MuraNava/posts/jgXwYfDRq9Z]
http://203.72.145.166/tesol/tqd_2008/VOL_41_2.pdf
ns0:entry.ns0:title: #Phrasal #verbs duh duh duh!

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
Costas Gabrielatos a linguist from Edge HIll University has kindly answered some questions I posed to him.

----------
1. Tell us a little about your background.
 
I started as a language teacher, and then moved to teacher education. Almost from the beginning, I got more interested in the ‘language’ side of ‘language teaching’ – a main contributing reason being the high frequency of overgeneralisations and inaccuracies in the information (‘rules’) provided in coursebooks and pedagogical grammars. This led me to corpus-based linguistics, but with an eye to pedagogical implications. My currently focus, as far as LT is concerned, is on corpus-based pedagogical grammar and analysis of learner language. 
 
2. Why should teachers consider #corpora in their classroom?
 
I think ‘should’ might be a bit too strong. More to the point, I think encouraging teachers to adopt corpus-based teaching approaches irrespective of their knowledge/skills is simply misguided. Before teachers (or researchers, for that matter) attempt to use corpus-based techniques, they need to have acquired relevant knowledge and skills. I’ve observed enough lessons based on misunderstood notions of ‘communicative teaching’ to shudder at the idea of a hasty adoption of CL techniques in language teaching. However, given the knowledge/skills, then access to corpora can enrich any teaching approach – provided, of course, that the approach does not allow ‘rules’ to trump evidence of actual language use.
 
3. Why do you think take up of it has been slow if not non-existent?
 
Lack of knowledge and skills, and perhaps lack of time and/or interest. Another possibility is the perception of corpus-based approaches as rather ‘academic’ (cue in the stereotypical aloof lecturer and lab-coated researcher). In fact, in light of my previous answer, I don’t find the current low level of adoption something to be unhappy about.
 
4. Do you think that is changing with wider availability of corpus interfaces such as COCA?
 
Judging from the increasing number of relevant journal papers, conference presentations, discussion groups, and websites/blogs, the interest in the utility of CL techniques for language teaching appears to be rising. However, it seems to me that the increase in interest is not so much on the part of what we might call traditional classroom teachers, but those who teach in universities, or are involved in online language teaching, or are in the process of moving away from the (virtual) classroom and towards academia.
 
5. Do you know to what extent the Lancaster corpus MOOC would interest teachers?
 
I can’t tell if it would interest teachers, but I think it offers a very good way in for those considering adding corpus-based elements to their teaching. Not only because there is a component on corpora and language teaching, but also, and more importantly, because the MOOC introduces participants to the core concepts, constructs and techniques in CL.
 
6. Can you recommend just one reference/resource to help language teachers with corpora?
 
The short answer is: ‘I refuse to do that’. The longer answer is that I think it is limiting and educationally detrimental to only derive information from a single source. CL is not monolithic, and there are currently a lot of disputes regarding some of its core theoretical notions and analytical approaches – even the very nature of CL is being debated (for example, see https://benjamins.com/#catalog/journals/ijcl.15.3/toc ). My advice would be to read as many introductory chapters/books by different authors as possible and, in typical CL fashion,  try to identify patterns in approaches and practices – keeping in mind that newer introductions are not necessarily better than older ones.
 
7. Any comments you would like to add not yet covered?
 
Just a few things I always stress at the beginning of a CL module/seminar:
·      Corpus linguistics is something you learn primarily by doing: working with corpus tools and reflecting critically on both the results you get and the techniques that yielded these results.
·      If you expect the ease and automaticity that would be afforded by a StarTrek-type computer, you’ll be disappointed – CL involves a lot of manual work.
·      Corpus linguistics is very easy to do badly.
 
For a detailed account of my views on corpora and language teaching, see here: http://tesl-ej.org/ej32/a1.html

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
#Corpus Linguistics in fiction.

My wife is reading a #DavidLodge novel called Deaf Sentence (French title - La vie en sourdine) and mentioned to me that there is a passage in the book (bottom of page 232 to top of page 234 - http://books.google.fr/books?id=U2MMEMw9wzIC&lpg=PA234&ots=FBUT0K16Xl&dq=deaf%20sentence%20corpus%20linguistics&pg=PA232#v=onepage&q&f=false) looking at the #collocates of happy and deaf.  Two #corpora are used one of size 1.5 million and one of size 50 million ("the biggest available").

So my question is can anyone figure out the two corpora that are referred to?

The novel was published in 2008.
http://books.google.fr/books?id=U2MMEMw9wzIC&lpg=PA234&ots=FBUT0K16Xl&dq=deaf+sentence+corpus+linguistics&pg=PA232#v=onepage&q&f=false

ns0:entry.ns0:content:
#BNC14 media blitz

This post has been cut as requested by Robbie Love. It shows the questions I asked but not the responses as you have to now get information about BNC14 through official channels only. Note added his reflections on the whole media experience near end of post.

You may have noticed a number of newspaper articles/interviews reporting on initial findings of BNC14 spoken #corpus . See end of this post for a list.

I had a few questions about what I read and Robbie Love one of the researchers on the project kindly agreed to answer these but I can't report them here.

Q1: Is figure of 155 instances per million for marvellous correct? As I found 31.8 from BNC web?

Q2: How many tokens make up the approx. 200 recordings that have been used?

Q3: There was a tweet saying you are looking for 'native' speakers could you clarify this?

Final comments by Robbie: Information about the project, and how to participate, can be found here:

http://cass.lancs.ac.uk/?p=1335

Importantly, we’re encouraging speakers to email corpus@cambridge.org to participate in the project.

Thanks to Robbie for taking time to answer these questions even if you can't read them here and if you feel like contributing recordings to get in touch with him. Although there is monetary compensation for your efforts what is more attractive is that the corpus will be made available to the public.

One final thing is that most of the media reports focused on the American English dominating angle, if you look at COCA for example the same patterns in rise in awesome and decline in marvelous (note single l) can be seen in US English -
https://googledrive.com/host/0B7FW2BYaBgeieUlZTDNXT1hzVnM/Awesome_MarvelousUSSpokenEnglish.png

Media report list:

No longer marvellous... now everything is awesome: How Britons are using more American words because traditional English is in decline
[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2733912/No-longer-marvellous-awesome-Britons-using-American-words-traditional-English-decline.html]

From marvellous to awesome: how spoken British English has changed
[http://www.theguardian.com/science/shortcuts/2014/aug/26/british-english-words-endangered-awesome-marvellous]

Awesome! How American words are changing the way we speak
[http://www.express.co.uk/news/uk/503279/Americanisms-changing-the-way-we-speak]

‘Pussy cat’, ‘marvellous’ and ‘cheerio’ – just some of the words that no longer exist in our vocab
[http://metro.co.uk/2014/08/25/pussy-cat-marvellous-and-cheerio-just-some-of-the-words-that-no-longer-exist-in-our-vocab-4845616/]

British people use more American words than ever due to rise of the digital age
[http://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/british-people-use-more-american-4106418]

Cheerio Marvellous... You're No Longer Awesome
[http://news.sky.com/story/1324831/cheerio-marvellous-youre-no-longer-awesome]

BBC Radio 4 - English language becomes more Americanised (starts at 27:58)
[http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b04f85bf]

Why marvellous isn't awesome anymore
[http://phys.org/news/2014-08-marvellous-isnt-awesome.html]

10 words that are dying out - but 'cheerio' is alive and well in Plymouth, says Argyle fan
[http://www.plymouthherald.co.uk/10-words-dying-cheerio-alive-Plymouth-says-Argyle/story-22847155-detail/story.html]

Cheerio marvellous: The words disappearing from the English vocabulary
[http://www.itv.com/news/2014-08-26/cheerio-marvellous-the-words-disappearing-from-the-english-vocabulary/]

Swimming in the deep end of the Spoken BNC2014 media frenzy [http://cass.lancs.ac.uk/?p=1407]

Modern men rein in the sexist language: Analysis finds terms like sexy or blonde have disappeared from vocabulary when women are referred to
[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2889427/Men-rein-sexist-language-Analysis-finds-terms-like-sexy-blonde-disappeared-vocabulary-women-referred-to.html]
